Current Performance Metrics, especially those applied to the core
, derive from a general perspective approach, only based on a
Network-oriented point of view, therefore unconnected to the kind of
But, due to the growing need to face the complexity of the new IP
, especially while trying to detect the impact of a
measurement on a particular service. For instance, if a
or a link has a 10-4 average PLR, does this impact on the kind
Moreover, this general perspective approach is unsuited to perceive
various factors to be taken into account, such as:
specificity of the service, with its own protocol, application
. coding), and management (i.e. QOS, fragmentation management)
kind of network topology over which the particular service is
A trivial but clarifying example of this occurs when the same PLR is
over two different links: one of the link coming out from the
(source) of a multicast tree, and the other link ending with a
The impact on the service, of course, is dramatically different if the
cases are considered separately, since the first kind of link
the whole set of flows originating from the source, while the
one conveys just a subset of the whole set of flows.
As a consequence of the above consideration, a Service-oriented point of
View - more centred on the particular kind of service, and its own
characteristics - must be taken into account while defining
effort to a deeper analysis and definition of spatial aggregation
(as a part of the framework for metric composition defined in
RFC 5835 [RFC5835]), thus assigning a sort of weight, specific, and
for each link, to the PLR measured over it, in order to take
account the impact of the PLR on the service.

This memo lends itself to passive measurement as well as active
(with dedicated test traffic). In reality, if the

This is a key area to address further.
Finally this memo is tuned to RFC 6390 [RFC6390] in terms of scopes,
concepts, and need to widen the current performance metrics
are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119 [RFC2119].
The names of the metrics, including capitalized letters, are as close as
of the names of the one-way end-to-end or one-to-group metrics
The points of interest correspond to the hosts (according to the RFC
2330 definition, "hosts" include routing nodes), - i.e. measurement
points - which are a sub-set of the set of hosts involved in
delivery of the packets (in addition to the source itself).
In RFC 5644 two possible scenarios concerning the points of interest
spatial one, and one-to-group) have been considered.
For the purpose of this memo a sort of mixed scenario, among the ones
above, is taken into account. In fact the whole set of the hosts
a multicast tree, including destinations, are points of
. An example of a very simple multicast tree, and its related
of interest is depicted in Fig. 1.
(*) represent the nodes that are points of interest
Figure 1: Points of Interest for a multicast tree
A generic single-source multicast tree, like the very simple one
in Fig.2, is composed by J links, and X receivers.
Figure 2: Example of a whole (or part of) multicast tree
To accomplish the task of this memo, an equivalent representation of the
single-source multicast tree is proposed, which is obtained by
it in X different Multicast Equivalent Paths (called ME-Paths,
now on), each of them corresponding to one of the X different paths
better explained below - starting from the source, and ending up
The generic ME-Path x is composed by the sequence of hosts, and
links between the source, and the receiver x.
As a result, the ME-Paths are different from each other because even if
can partially overlap, they never do it completely. This happens
each ME-Path is different from all the other ones regarding at
one link, the one ending on the receiver, belonging just to one

The purpose of this memo is to enrich the current Performance metrics -
derived from a Network-oriented point of view, and therefore a
perspective, which is not focused on specific services - with
more Performance factors, so to include a Service-oriented point
view as well, more centred on:
specificity of the service or services to be monitored, with their
protocols, applications (i.e. coding), and management (i.e. QOS,
kind of network topology over which the service or services to be
To accomplish this task a weighing factor
Link j, is introduced. Thus each Type-P-One-to-group-
Link-j-Loss-Ratio is weighed through its own specific

Some, but not all, of the possible network, and/or service factors that
be taken into account while characterizing

- the so called Overlapping Factor - is
As discussed in section 2, ME-Paths can partially overlap, thus
one or more links (e.g. Link 1 in Fig. 2). As a result, a
Link j can belong to more than one ME-Path. A consequence of
fact is that the more the ME-Paths the generic Link j belongs to,
more a packet loss over that link impacts the service it conveys.
For instance, even if the same packet loss is detected both over a link
out from the root (source) of a multicast tree, and over a link
on a receiver, the impact on the service is dramatically
As a consequence, the Overlapping Factor MUST be taken into account
Considering this, a question arises: how to expressly include it in the
, following the dynamic topology changes of the multicast tree.
A possible way to solve this problem is to take the Overlapping Factor
account just implicitly, while calculating the final

7.1. Extended applications to multi-source one-to-group topology
All the above discussion is applicable both to a single-source
topology, and to a multi-source one-to-group topology.
In fact, given one single group flowing from several sources - thus
from several groups flowing from several sources, that is a
group topology - each host chooses just one, and only one
at a time from which the flow is accepted, thus leading
back to the single-source one-to-group situation already dealt with
7.2. Extended applications to One-way Delay and Delay Variation
The framework proposed in this memo is wide enough to be applicable not
to the Packet Loss analysis, but also to the One-way Delay, and
This goal is achievable by adequately defining
Anyway, this is out of the scope of this memo, and it will be deepened
and one-to-group metrics are defined on the top of end-to-end
. Security considerations discussed in the one-way delay
definitions of [RFC2679], in packet loss metrics definitions
[RFC2680], and in IPDV metrics definitions of [RFC3393], and
[RFC3432] apply to metrics defined in this memo.
Someone may spoof the identity of a point of interest identity, and
send corrupt results in order to remotely orient the
A point of interest could intentionally corrupt its results in order
remotely orient the traffic engineering decisions.
Reporting of measurement results from a huge number of probes
The configuration of a measurement must take into consideration that
more packets will be routed than sent and select a test
rate accordingly. Collecting statistics from a huge number of
may overload any combination of the network to which the
controller is attached, measurement controller network
One-to-group metric measurements should consider using source
protocols, standardized in the MSEC group, to avoid
packet in the sampling interval. The test packet rate could be
before any measurement session to avoid denial-of-service
A point of interest could intentionally degrade its results in order
remotely increase the quality of the network on the branches of
multicast tree to which it is connected.
